title: 108_hr1106
content:
The Act titled the "Fremont-Madison Conveyance Act" defines terms like "District" and "Secretary" before discussing the conveyance of facilities. The Fremont-Madison Conveyance Act requires the Secretary of the Interior to convey water distribution and drainage system components to the Fremont-Madison Irrigation District in Idaho. The conveyance must be consistent with a memorandum of agreement between the District and the Secretary. The Secretary must convey water distribution and drainage system components to the Fremont-Madison Irrigation District in Idaho, consistent with a memorandum of agreement. If conveyance is not completed by September 13, 2004, a report must be submitted to Congress explaining the delay and providing a new completion date. SEC. 4. COSTS. The Secretary requires the District to pay administrative costs and the net present value of remaining obligations for the conveyance of facilities. The District must pay the lesser of the net present value of remaining obligations or $280,000 to the United States for the conveyed facilities. Amounts received will go into the Reclamation Fund. The Secretary will convey the Teton Exchange Wells, including a water permit and equipment, to the District. The water service contract between the Secretary and the District is extended until all conditions in the Act are met. SEC. 6. ENVIRONMENTAL REVIEW

Before conveyance, the Secretary must complete all environmental reviews as outlined in the Memorandum of Agreement referenced in section 3(a).

SEC. 7. LIABILITY

After conveyance, the United States will not be liable for damages related to the conveyed facilities, except for negligence prior to the conveyance date. This does not increase the liability beyond what is currently provided in chapter 171 of title 28, United States Code. SEC. 8. WATER SUPPLY TO DISTRICT LANDS: The acreage eligible for water from the Minidoka and Teton Basin Projects in the District is increased to include all current and annexed lands. This increase does not affect existing water contracts or state water law. SEC. 9. DROUGHT MANAGEMENT PLANNING. Within 60 days of enactment, the Secretary will collaborate with stakeholders in the Henry's Fork watershed to initiate a drought management planning process for all water uses. Within 18 months, a final drought management plan will be submitted to Congress. The Act does not affect existing rights to water of the Shoshone-Bannock Tribes based on treaties, compacts, or laws. Conveyances under the Act will not impact contracts or state laws regarding irrigation districts' water rights.
